Andy wrote:
Our Java app was developed and tested on Windows, using an mySq=
l database.
Now, during our testing on linux, suddenly our app stopped work=
ing. Turns
out our embedded SQL statement had a mixture of case for table a=
nd column
names. This case mixture wasn't a problem on windows, but is on l=
inux.

My opinions:
1.This can also happen, when you put 
all the SQL in th=
e resource bundle.
2.Embedded SQL (Oracle: Pro C/C++ or SQLJ) is ugly. 
You=
r code is getting littered with machine generated junk.
Use OCI or JDBC.
3.=
 Even if you have all the SQL in the resource bundle, 
there is usually a n=
eed to modify the statements dynamically at
runtime in your Java code.
4. I=
 also worked successfully with SQL in the resource bundle.
But the dynamic =
modification had to take place in the Java/C++
code. So why not incorporate=
 the SQL templates in the
java code. Moreover this requires less discipline=
 than
putting the SQL templates in the resource bundle. Therefore
it is mor=
e likely, that this coding guideline is getting obeyed.

Just my 2 cents
